court:
HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM
PRESENT
THE HONOURABLE MR
petitioners: 4 AJAY SATHEESH, AGED 29 YEARS, S/0.SATHEESH KUMAR,
POOVANNIL VEEDU, KURAKKANNI DESOM, VARKALA P.0O.,VARKALA
2 RAJEEV, AGED 41 YEARS, S/0.PRAKASH, SARAS VEEDU, NEAR
AMMAN KOVIL, KURAKKANNI DESOM, VARKALA P.0., VARKALA
3 MARTIN, AGED 37 YEARS, S/0O.THOMAS, PUTHUVAL PUTHEN
VEEDU, THODUVE, KANNAMBA DESOM, VARKALA P.0., VARKALA
respondents: 1 STATE OF KERALA, REPRESENTED BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH
2 THE STATION HOUSE OFFICER, VARKALA POLICE STATION,
RESIDING AT BINU MANZIL, THOKADU, PANAYARA P 0O.,
outcome:
ORDER

Petitioners have invoked the jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C
to quash all proceedings against them.

2. Petitioners are accused Nos.1 to 3 in C.P.No.119/2023 on the
files of the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court, Varkala arising out of
Crime No.1870/2023 of Varkala Police Station, Thiruvananthapuram
District registered for the offences under Sections 294(b), 341, 323, 324
and 308 r/w Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. Third
respondent is the defacto complainant.

3. The prosecution alleges that on 03.10.2023 the accused
restrained the complainant due to previous enmity and assaulted him
and thereby committed the offences alleged.

4. Heard the learned Counsel for the petitioners and the learned
Counsel for the respondent apart from the learned Public Prosecutor.

5. The learned Public Prosecutor pointed out that the 2" petitioner,
who is the 2™ accused is a habitual offender and is involved in 11 other
crimes of which 9 are of the Varkala Police Station, as Crime
Nos.847/2013, 607/2019, 688/2019, 1599/2017, 1886/2014, 4439/2020,

Baan
2024/KER/6451
CRL.MC NO. 114 OF 2024
3
267/2021, 280/2021, 1979/2021, 442/2021 and 1870/2023, which
includes offences under Sections 307, 326, 308 and even Section 27 of
the Arms Act. However, it was pointed that petitioners 1 and 3 are not
involved in any other crimes of Varkala Police Station.

6. In Gian Singh v. State of Punjab [(2012) 10 SCC 303], the
Apex Court has held that in appropriate cases, the High Court can take
note of the amicable resolution of disputes between the victim and the
wrongdoer to put an end to the criminal proceedings. This view was
reiterated in Narinder Singh v. State of Punjab [(2014) 6 SCC 466]
and Yogendra Yadav and Others v. State of Jharkhand and
Another [(2014) 9 SCC 653].

7. Though petitioners and defacto complainant are alleged to
have settled the entire disputes as evident from Annexure A3, which has
been verified by the learned Public Prosecutor through the Investigating
Officer, | am of the view that considering the criminal antecedents of the
24 petitioner, quashing of the crime on the basis of the settlement as
against him may not be conducive to public interest. The nature of
offences and the other crimes stand against him in quashing the
proceedings as against the 2™ petitioner. As far as petitioners 1 and 3,
are concerned, since there are no criminal antecedents and the matter
has been settled with the defacto complainant, this Court is of the view
that the proceedings against those petitioners can be quashed

ORDER

Petitioners have invoked the jurisdiction under Section 482 Cr.P.C
to quash all proceedings against them.

2. Petitioners are accused Nos.1 to 3 in C.P.No.119/2023 on the
files of the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court, Varkala arising out of

and 308 r/w Section 34 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. Third
respondent is the defacto complainant.

restrained the complainant due to previous enmity and assaulted him
and thereby committed the offences alleged.

5. The learned Public Prosecutor pointed out that the 2" petitioner,
who is the 2™ accused is a habitual offender and is involved in 11 other
crimes of which 9 are of the Varkala Police Station, as Crime
Nos.847/2013, 607/2019, 688/2019, 1599/2017, 1886/2014, 4439/2020,

267/2021, 280/2021, 1979/2021, 442/2021 and 1870/2023, which
includes offences under Sections 307, 326, 308 and even Section 27 of

8. In the result, all proceedings against petitioners 1 and 3, who
